Sure! In the Dutch Republic, citizens had the right to vote for representatives who would then form the government. These representatives were selected through a complex process involving multiple rounds of voting and various levels of government. 

At the local level, citizens would elect representatives to a municipal council. These councils would then select representatives to a provincial assembly. Finally, members of the provincial assembly would choose representatives to the States General, which was the federal governing body of the Dutch Republic.

The States General had the power to make laws and decisions that affected the entire country. However, each of the provinces had a high degree of autonomy and could make their own laws on many issues.

The Dutch Republic's representative democracy was effective in promoting the direct participation of citizens in government, and it allowed for a degree of local autonomy while still maintaining a strong central government.
